title: Synthetic Recap
body:
ATLANTA (AP) – On a night when offense was a precious commodity, one man authored a masterpiece. Dominique Wilkins, “The Human Highlight Film,” turned back the clock and delivered a performance for the ages, single-handedly lifting the Atlanta Hawks to a grueling 95-90 victory over the rival Boston Celtics.

In a defensive battle where no other player could crack 20 points, Wilkins was an unstoppable force of nature. He poured in a game-high **42 points**, a staggering offensive output in a contest defined by grit and grind. Every time the Celtics threatened to seize momentum, Wilkins answered with a dagger—a silky jumper from the wing, a powerful drive through the lane, or a thunderous fast-break dunk that sent the home crowd into a frenzy.

While Wilkins provided the firepower, the Hawks’ defense was the unsung hero. Dikembe Mutombo, the league’s premier shot-blocker, anchored the paint with **4 blocks** and **13 rebounds**, dissuading Celtic drives at every turn. His presence allowed Wilkins to gamble on the perimeter, knowing the rim was protected.

Boston fought valiantly, led by Rick Fox’s **19 points** and Dee Brown’s **15**, but they had no answer for the Wilkins onslaught. In the final, tense minutes, it was the legend who took over, scoring Atlanta's critical final baskets to seal the win. It was more than just a victory; it was a historic night where one superstar, through sheer force of will, refused to let his team lose.
